description: Nikola Petrak privately authorizes the full public release of all BCI decision archives, trusting teacher-led assemblies to manage community response and interpretation. He notifies a small circle of teacher representatives and veteran engineers.

Under pressure from outspoken teacher-citizen forums, Nikola's decision is announced: all BCI decision archives, detailing decades of score manipulation and hidden biases, will be released for public review.

Teams of citizen volunteers and veteran engineers, coordinated by teacher leaders, begin sorting through BCI data. Early findings expose systemic score tampering favoring Council-aligned sectors and quiet suppression of dissenters.

News of BCI abuses triggers citywide outrage. Grassroots tribunals appear in districts across Stenograd: teachers, citizens, and former officials confront records of injustice. Demands for confessions, justice, and restitution spread.

Council factions are forced into televised confessions, some admitting collusion and manipulation under Halden's tenure. Public trust in central authority nears collapse, but teacher-led forums emerge as new civic anchors.
